TypeSignature.Value: .class public interface auto ansi abstract HTMLProject implements class Microsoft.Office.Core._IMsoDispObj

Docs.summary: Represents a top-level project branch, as in the Project Explorer in the Microsoft Script Editor.

remarks.para: Use the method of the object to open an HTML project in the Microsoft Script Editor. The project is opened in source view or text view for the active Microsoft Word document, Excel workbook, or PowerPoint presentation.

Use the property to return the collection of HTMLProjectItem objects in the HTML project. Use the method to refresh the HTML document in the host application. Use the method to refresh the project in the Microsoft Script Editor. Use the method to determine whether the HTML project needs to be refreshed.

MemberSignature.Value: public object Application { get; }
.property instance object Application
Public ReadOnly Property Application As Object
public: property System::Object ^ Application { System::Object ^ get(); };

Docs.summary: Returns an Application object that represents the container application for the object.

MemberSignature.Value: public int Creator { get; }
.property instance int32 Creator
Public ReadOnly Property Creator As Integer
public: property int Creator { int get(); };

Docs.summary: Returns a 32-bit integer that indicates the application in which the specified object was created.

remarks.para: If the object was created in Microsoft Word, this property returns 1297307460, which represents the string MSWD; if created in Microsoft Excel, this property returns 1480803660. This value can also be represented by the constant wdCreatorCode in Word, or xlCreatorCode in Excel.

The Creator property was primarily designed to be used on the Macintosh, where each application has a four-character creator code. For example, Microsoft Word has the creator code MSWD. For additional information about this property, consult the language reference Help included with Microsoft Office Macintosh Edition.

The Creator property always returns the numeric identifier for the active application, just as the property always returns the name of the active application in string form. Use the CreatedBy property of the , , , and objects to return the name of the individual who created those objects. Use document properties to return information about the authors of Office documents.

MemberSignature.Value: public Microsoft.Office.Core.HTMLProjectItems HTMLProjectItems { get; }
.property instance class Microsoft.Office.Core.HTMLProjectItems HTMLProjectItems
Public ReadOnly Property HTMLProjectItems As HTMLProjectItems
public: property Microsoft::Office::Core::HTMLProjectItems ^ HTMLProjectItems { Microsoft::Office::Core::HTMLProjectItems ^ get(); };

Docs.summary: Returns the collection that is included in the specified HTML project.

MemberSignature.Value: public void Open (Microsoft.Office.Core.MsoHTMLProjectOpen OpenKind = (Microsoft.Office.Core.MsoHTMLProjectOpen) 0);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void Open([in]valuetype Microsoft.Office.Core.MsoHTMLProjectOpen OpenKind) runtime managed
Public Sub Open (Optional OpenKind As MsoHTMLProjectOpen = (Microsoft.Office.Core.MsoHTMLProjectOpen) 0)

Docs.param: Optional . The view in which the specified project or project item is opened.
Docs.summary: Opens the specified HTML project or HTML project item in the Microsoft Script Editor in one of the views specified by the optional constants.

remarks.para: If one of the constants is not specified, the project item is opened in the default view.

The default view is determined by whether or not the Microsoft Script Editor is open when the Open method is executed. If the Script Editor is not open, the Open method starts the Script Editor in source view. If the Script Editor is already open, the Open method activates the Script Editor and displays the script in the current view.

MemberSignature.Value: public object Parent { get; }
.property instance object Parent
Public ReadOnly Property Parent As Object
public: property System::Object ^ Parent { System::Object ^ get(); };

Docs.summary: Returns the Parent object for the specified object.

MemberSignature.Value: public void RefreshDocument (bool Refresh = false);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void RefreshDocument([in]bool Refresh) runtime managed
Public Sub RefreshDocument (Optional Refresh As Boolean = false)

Docs.param: Optional Boolean. True if all changes are to be saved; False if all changes are to be ignored.
Docs.summary: Refreshes the specified HTML project in the Microsoft Office host application.

remarks.para: Using this method is equivalent to clicking the Refresh button on the Refresh toolbar in the Office host application. If you refresh the document by setting the RefreshDocument method to True, all changes to the HTML source made in the Microsoft Script Editor are saved in the Office host application. If you set RefreshDocument to False, all changes to the HTML source are ignored.

Note that the value returned by the property is affected by the RefreshDocument method. If you call RefreshDocument(True), the State property returns msoHTMLProjectStateDocumentProjectUnlocked if it is called after the refresh operation.

MemberSignature.Value: public void RefreshProject (bool Refresh = false);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void RefreshProject([in]bool Refresh) runtime managed
Public Sub RefreshProject (Optional Refresh As Boolean = false)

Docs.param: Optional Boolean. True if the document will be refreshed; False if the document will not be refreshed.
Docs.summary: Refreshes the specified HTML project in the Microsoft Script Editor.

remarks.para: Using this method is equivalent to clicking the Refresh button on the Refresh toolbar in the Microsoft Script Editor. If you refresh the document by setting to True, all changes to the HTML source made in the Office host application are saved to the HTML project in the Microsoft Script Editor. If you set RefreshDocument to False, all changes to the HTML source are ignored.
